isis.stitle: MOR/RYDE RUBBER SPRING SUSPENSION - REPLACEMENT - RUBBER SPRINGS

svcprocinfo.para: The rubber springs are vulcanized (bonded) to plates ( Figure 3). There are two conditions that may occur with the rubber springs.

item.para: The first condition is a bond failure. The rubber separates from the metal plate.
The second condition is a rubber failure. The rubber tears or delaminates and generally occurs in the middle of the rubber spring between the metal plates.

svcprocinfo.para: Either of the conditions described above would not always necessitate replacement of the rubber spring. If there is a question about the integrity of a marginal rubber spring, a 3" (76mm) wide object (such as a 3" putty knife) can be used to probe the rubber spring in the affected area. If the probe penetrates the crack or separated area .75 inch (19mm) or more, the spring should be replaced.

note.para: The rubber spring assembly is actually two (2) individual rubber springs with the 8.50 x 11.0 steel plates bolted back-to-back ( Figure 3). If only one spring in the assembly is defective, it is necessary to replace only the defective individual rubber spring - not the entire assembly.

step1.para: Make sure vehicle is elevated, chassis is supported with safety stands, the front wheels blocked, and the suspension hanging unsupported.
Remove 3/8" bolts securing the rubber spring assembly to beam assembly and to frame hanger assembly ( Figure 4).

figure.caption: Figure 4. RUBBER SPRING ASSEMBLY AND HANGER ASSEMBLY

step1.para: Rubber spring assembly can now be removed by pulling downward and out. (Spring assembly cannot be removed by forcing upward.)

svcsubproc.title: Install
svcsubproc.para: Install new spring assembly by pushing spring assembly upward (either by hand or with jack) between the beam assembly and frame hanger assemblies until the bolt holes are aligned ( Figure 4). Secure spring assembly with 3/8" x 7/8" Grade 8 bolts. Tighten bolts to 35 ft-lbs. (47 N•m).
